content: There are two types of quantities that you should know of: Scalars and Vectors
A scalar only has magnitude and is specified by a real number. Examples of such scalars are mass, speed, distance, volume and time. They have one value "attaced" to them and thats it.
In the example above, $ \text{ Temperature } $ is the quantity, $273$ is the magnitude, and $K$ is the unit.
A vector has both magnitude and direction. They are specified by a real number and a direction. Examples of vectors are forces, displacement, velocity and acceleration.
In the example above, $ \text{ Force } $ is the quantity, $10$ is the magnitude, $N$ is the unit and $ [ \text{ NW } ] $ is the direction.
Vectors can be written in two ways.
Typically in physics and other subjects, vectors are written as a variable with an arrow above them: $ \vec {a} $, $ \vec{F} $, $ \vec {d} $
They are also written as two points $ \overrightarrow {AB} $ where the vector points from points $A$ to $B$.

You may be most familiar with cartesian representation, since it resembles points on a graph.
The cartesian representation of vectors consists of a ordered pair of coordinates as follows:
In this representation, you draw an arrow from the origin $ (0, \ 0) $ to the coordinates $ (x, \ y) $. The arrow's "head" points at the ordered coordinate pair.

The polar representation of a vector consists of a magnitude (length) denoted as $n$ as well as an angle that it makes with the positive x-axis denoted as $ \theta $.
The magnitude is always positive, and the angle is positive in the clockwise direction.
Here is what it looks like on a graph:
Both cartesian and polar coordinates can easily be converted from one to the other.
As stated previously, cartesian coordinates are a pair of $x$ and $y$ coordinates. You can actually use trigonometry to calculate the magnitude and angle of the vector!
Think of the vector as a right angle triangle. For the magnitude, you need to get the hypotenus. For the angle, you need to get the angle between the vector's arrow and the positive x-axis.

Algebraic vectors are the vectors that we have seen up to now. They are vectors that have a reference to some coordinate axes/plane.

Geometric vectors are vectors without a reference frame. Their magnitude is identified by the length of the vector itself, and their direction is indicated by the orientation of the vector.

As of now, we have only dealt with vectors in second dimension, or $ \mathbb{R}^2 $. Vectors in the 3rd dimension, or $ \mathbb{R}^3 $ are very similar.
Instead of two coordinates, they have three:

In fact, vectors are not only limited to $ \mathbb{R}^2 $ or $ \mathbb{R}^3 $. They be in any dimension $ \mathbb{R}^n $ where $n$ is any real number, however, it may be difficult for you to visualize it, since you live only in the 3rd dimension!
The unit vector is vector that points in a certain direction, and has a magnitude equal to $1$.
You can think of the unit vector as a "direction" vector. Whatever constant you multiply to it, its magnitude will be equal to that constant.
For example, the vector $ \vec {v} = (\frac {1} {\sqrt{2}}, \ \frac {1} {\sqrt{2}}) $ is a unit vector.

Vectors can be written as a combination of the unity vectors $ \hat {i} $, $ \hat {j} $ and $ \hat {k} $, where $ \hat {i} = (1, \ 0 , \ 0) $, $ \hat {j} = (0, \ 1 , \ 0) $ and $ \hat {k} = (0, \ 0 , \ 1) $.

For example, the vector $ \vec {v} = (2, \ -3, \ 4) $ can be written as $ \vec {v} = 2 \hat {i} - 3 \hat {j} + 4 \hat {k} $. This is because the sum of the unit vectors times their coefficents equals $ \vec {v} $.
